app.rdg: The materials of the following Tragedy are taken partly from the splendid narrative of Gibbon; partly from the still more graphical and interesting account of Rienzi’s eventful career, contained in the second volume of L’Abbe de Sade’s Memoires pour servir a la Vie de Petrarque; and, as far as the female characters are concerned, entirely from invention.

So much for the play. To such of my readers as may have witnessed Mr. Young’s performance of its hero, my feeble eulogium would, indeed, be superfluous, especially as, by the publication of the piece, I have enabled them to appreciate the delicate touches which belong exclusively to the performer. Still, I cannot
refrain from adding to my cordial thanks, one tribute, which none but the Authoress can pay; by declaring, with unfeigned sincerity, that the image present to my fancy, when writing that long and arduous part, has been perfectly and vividly embodied by the great actor to whom it has been so fortunately entrusted. To Mr. Cooper, I owe a double debt: as an actor, for his pure and affecting performance of Angelo; and, as a manager, for his ability in arranging the complicated business of the scene; and for the kindness and courtesy with which he lightened the labour of the preparations, to all who had a share in them. To Mrs. Faucit, I would in particular express my acknowledgments, for the discrimination and energy which she bestowed on a character important in the piece, but not calculated to reward the actress; whilst, to Miss Phillips, I owe an obligation of a different sort, for the pathos, the intelligence, and the modest sweetness, which, on their first development, have so enchanted the theatrical world. It is to me one of the most gratifying circumstances attendant on the production of Rienzi, that it has been
the medium of introducing to the acted drama, a young lady so fitted to adorn it, by every womanly grace. In short, to all the Performers, not only for the ability with which they filled their parts, but for the interest that they took in the general effect of the Play, I beg leave to offer my sincerest and warmest thanks.

In offering to the world a second edition of her Tragedy (the first impression of which was sold in three days), the Authoress has only to repeat her thanks to the excellent performers to who she was orignially indebted for success; and to acknowledge, with sincere gratitude, the almost unanimous kindness with which Rienzi, whether as an acted drama, or a published poem, has been received by the press.

The plot of this tragedy is founded on the history of Nicholas Rienzi, which Gibbon has described with such eloquence and power in the last volume of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire; and on the interesting account of his eventful career, contained in the second volume of L’Abbe de Sade’s Memoires pour servir a la Vie de Petrarque. The subject itself involves no very high degree of tragic interest. A plebeian band, struggling for liberty against two haughty an insolent factions—regaining it—becoming in turn the masters of their tyrants—using their freedom as an instrument of crueltly and oppression—and, with that fickleness and ingratitude wbich mark their character, turning their vengeance on the very idol on wbose head they would have lavished the names of senator or consul, of king or emperor. Thus, the oft told tale of aristocratical tyranny, and popular retribution, is again brought to our view. We hear the proud defiance of nobility, the spirit-stirring appeals of insulted patriotism, and the deafening shouts of a furious multitude, who hope much and understand little. But we miss the granduer of the Roman patron, the lofty bearing of the ancient patroit, who lived but for his country’s glory; and though the scene is laid in Rome, it is Rome in her most degenerate days, when torn and divided by contending factions: her race of heroes extinct, she was about to fall prey of fierce barbarians, and exhibit, in the solemn desolation of her seven hills—in her stately and majestic ruins, the most awful spectacle of the instability of human greatness in the history of mankind.

Rienzi, or as he styled himself in his theatrical pagents, “Tribune August,” and “Deliverer of Rome,” was a man descended from the lowest dregs of the people, the offspring of an innkeeper and a washerwoman. Having received from his parents the extraordinary gift of a liberal education, and from nature an inquiring, active, and intelligent mind, he raised himself from his obscure abd mean condition, to places both of honour adn profit: yet concealing, like the elder Brutus, under the mask of folly, and the character of a buffoon, a spirit that deepply deplored his country’s wrongs, and only wanted an opportunity to redress and avange them. In the feud between the rival houses of the Colonna and Ursini, he discovers some glimpse of the deliverence of Rome. A citizen who had refused to shout and throw up his ready cap during a triumphal procession of the latter party, is assaulted for his contumely. Rienzi, stung with rage at teh indignity offered to a Roman citizen, strike the offender to the ground—harangues the populace on their many and bitter wrongs—contrasts their ancient glory with their present degeneracy—rallies, expostulates, fires—and calls upon them to meet him at midnight on the Capitoline Hill. The summons obeyed—the spark of patriotism once kindled in their bosoms, their oppressors are instantly put down—Rienzi is elected Tribune of the people—justice, clemecy, and equal laws are promised to all—and the prostrate glories of the imperial city seem about to revive. But, as is the case in most revolutions, the downfall of one tyrant is only a prelude to the elevation of a still greater:—The Rienzi, invested with authority and power, is no longer the patroitic citizen, anxious only for the deliverance of his country: his nature is changed with his fortune; blinded and hurried on by sudden greatness, he becomes vain, sensual, arrogant, and cruel; affecting pomp and pageantry, violating the most sacred rites and symbols of religion; and exhibiting, in a still more odious degree, all the vices of the deposed faction, till, by a series of provocations, he offends the nobles beyond all hope of forgiveness; and by his pride intemperance, and pusillanimity, draws upon himself the hatred and contempt of the people; and from having been their champion and defender, he becomes, by an easy transition, their victim and sacrifice. Rienzi is drawn with great power: his courage, patroitism, and paternal tenderness, are finely brought out; while the vices that darken and degrade his character are shaded with such a skilful hand, that we cannot but regret, though we are fain to acknowledge the justice of his fall:—
Though stained with much ambition, he was one

In a drama founded on history, some allowance may be made for a departure from facts, when the interest of the scene demands it. Shakespeare never has recourse to invention when history is sufficient for his purpose: but, when its details prove tedious and unimportant, he augments or diminishes at his pleasure; still keeping in view the leading incidents, and preserving, as regards fable and character, the truth and spirit of his original. Miss Mitford has done no more than this; and, had she done less, her tragedy had been deficient in interest and effect. The female characters are entirely her own: the wily, imperious Lady Colonna; the delicate impassioned Claudia. The latter conception is eminently beautiful, and in perfect harmony with elegant mind form when it emanated. It combines sweetness, simplicity, and grace, with an heroic spirit tha aptly discovers itself in the most interesting crisis of the play:
Arm’d or unarm’d—as friend or foe—I’ll fly
To meet Lord Angelo! I am his wife—

If, in the character of Rienzi, Miss Mitford has shown that she can write with masculine energy, let Claudia bear witness that her wanton Dominion over the heart is still in full force; that with the power of agitating the soul by the fierce conflict of contending passions, a fine senssibility, a true pathos, a bewitching tenderness, are still her own to revive and illumine the dark shadows that veil the mysterious granduer of the tragic muse.
The sentiments are just and noble; the language is vigorous, picturesque, and poetical.
The domestic picture Act. III., Sc. II. beginning with
is in her happiest style; just and beautiful Rienzi’s injunction to his daughter; her images perfectly noble and almost sublime—and the whole equal to any thing in modern poetry.

I saw him plainly as thyself ; :— the form
Erect and stately; the proud head thrown back
Crested with waving plumes ! . Perchance, Camillo!
Claudia, with thine old Roman name, I gave thee
Precepts that might have made thee simply great ,
As ever maiden of old Rome. Camillo!
Wouldst thou deceive thy father? Pay’st thou thus Pay’est thou thus: is this how you repay
His love, his trust, his doting pride?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh, no!
No, no! I’ll tell thee all . : forgive me , father ! ,

Only forgive me!
— Thou shalt hear—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l:
Not now, my Claudia
. Cheer thee ; cheer thee, sweet! I’ll hear
Thy tale some fitter season. Wipe thine eyes.
If I’ve been harsh with thee , ’twas love, my Claudia,—
Love of my fairest daughter ! And , and vexed thoughts
Of this oppressed city. Sit thee , sweet!

app.rdg: They sit, C., Rienzi, L., Claudia, R.

sp.l: All is at peace between us . Weep : weep no more ,
My Claudia.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: This is joy.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: I had been chafed chafed: annoyed
By one of yon base minions. But the hour
Of vengeance comes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Of vengeance ? !

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Say, of freedom . : —
Dost tremble at the sound?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh, father , each
Alike is terrible , ; for each brings war ,
Fierce , desperate war.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Claudia, in these bad days,
When man must tread perforce the flinty path
Of Duty duty, hard and rugged, fail not thou
Duly duly: punctuallyat night and morning to give thanks
To the all-gracious power that smoothed the way
For woman’s tenderer feet. She but looks on ,
And waits , and prays for the good cause ; , whilst man
Fights, struggles, triumphs, dies. Vex not thy mind
All whom thou lov’st are safe . All silly trembler— ; all, silly trembler.
Peace ! Peace! I will not hear thee!—All , peace! I will not hear thee: all are safe.

Alberti, welcome ! .
Rienzi and Claudia rise.
Be the scrolls affixed
On churches, at street-corners, in the markets?
Art sure of the soldiers? Dost thou hold the guard watch ?
Thine answer in a word ! .

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: In one word — , yes.
All is prepared. I’m waited at the castle ;

Yet hearken, Cola
! ; I saw Count Savelli,
Thou hadst best avoid him.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Nay , confront him , rather ! :
I’ll to their palace ! Meet them! Baffle them! , meet them, baffle them.
Hast heard aught of the Ursini?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They feast
High and elate within their halls.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Yon wretch
Was not even missed ! . Poor slave, he shall be cared for. Yon wretch / Poor slave: Rienzi refers to the Ursini man he struck down
Now , for the last time—Simple child , in ! , in!
Lay all thy cares to rest. In, in, my child!

Bless thee , my Claudia! My my fair Claudia!
Puts her gently off , R .
Now
For Rome and Freedom.

div.stage: Exeunt , L .
End of the First Act END OF ACT I .

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Hall in the Colonna Palace.

Enter Colonna, Cafarello, and
Lady Colonna, and Nobles , R .

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
What ,
Martin Ursini our senator!

An Ursini
! And , and of that hated race
The most abhorred, the worst ! . He chief of Rome!
Sick, too. Tush! tush!

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: And , as I passed his palace, glancing lights
And sudden shouts and merry musick music spake
The high and liberal feasting which foreruns
Expected triumph.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Head of the state! and the Colonna fallen
Beneath their rivals’ rival’s feet! His wanton vassals,
The meanest horse-boys horseboys of his trainmeanest...train: his lowest servants, will spurn
My belted knights. Cousin , we must away
To Palestrina, and array in force
Our men at arms: they will be needed.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Fie!
These brawls match ill with thy white hairs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Good wife,
Wouldst have me turn a cravencraven: one who is defeated in mine age,
A by-word to mine enemies?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Art thou not
Stephen Colonna, of that greatest name

The greatest? Which of these , proud Ursini
,
May match with thee in fame? But thy old wreaths
Were won in nobler fields. These private feuds
Are grown a crying evil. —Count Savelli!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l:
A fair good evening , noble dame. Colonna
,
Hear’st thou the news?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Of Martin Ursini?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Nay , that were common , stale , and trivial. See ! ,
I bring ye tidings of rebellion, sirs;
High tidings! stirring tidings! prompt rebellion !
Headed—I prithee pr’ythee guess.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: Rare food for mirth,
If we may judge by look and tone. The wives
Of Rome revolted ? ; or the husbands risen
Against their gentle dames ? .

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: ’Tis a brief summons,
Fiery , but scholarly, stern , bold , and plain ,—
Calling the citizens to meet to-night
And win their freedom. Such a scroll as this
Is fixed in every street.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: How signed?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Guess ! , guess!
There lies the mirth . Ye’ll : ye’ll never guess—read here.

div.stage: Showing Crossing to C. and showing a scroll.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: What, Cola di Rienzi! honest Cola,
Who saves Colonna here a jester’s charge,
A fool without the bells ! . Honest Rienzi!
’Tis a device device: schemeof the black Ursini.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Likelier some freakfreak: whim of Cola’s. He hath turned
And mutters riddling warnings and wild tales
Of the great days of heathen Rome; and prates
Of peace, and liberty, and equal law,
And mild philosophy, to us the knights
And warriors of this warlike age, who rule
By the bright law of arms. The fool’s grown wise : —
A grievous change.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: I ever thought him so:
A sad wise man, of daring eye , and free,
Yet mystic speech. When ye have laughed , I still
Have shuddered for his darkling words, oft fell
Like oracles, answering with dim response
To my unspoken thoughts, so that my spirit,
Albeit unused to womanish fear, hath quail’d
To hear his voice’s deep vibration. Watch him!

Be sure, he is ambitious. —
Watch him, lords ! :— : —
He hath o’erleapt the barrier , poverty , ;
Hath conquered his mean parentage , ; hath clomb
The pontiff’s notarypontiff’s notary: Rienzi is an official in the service of the church, the honoured friend
Of Petrarch. Watch him well.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Tush, tush! Rienzi—
Cola Rienzi—honest Cola, rise

’Gainst us! Fair wife , I deemed thee wiser. —
They
Who plot are silent. Would we were as sure
Of Martin Ursini! What says Avignon?
The holy father hath not joined the faction?

div.stage: Enter Rienzi, behind , L., unseen .

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: I know not ; , but the cardinals, his uncles,
Are powerful with Pope Clement.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: All the race,
Churchmen or laiclaic: laymen; secular, old or young, have craftcraft: deceit; cunning

Veined in their stony hearts , — the master
- streak
Of that cold marble. Of the cardinals,
Gaetano is a soldier-priest, but wary,
And politic as valiant; Annibal,
A meek soft-spoken monk , who , crawling , climbs
Ambition’s loftiest ladder. Of the nephews — ,

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Despatch them at a stroke . Say ,—say they’re thy foes.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Why, master Cola—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Say they are thy foes.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Art thou their friend? I have heard talk of wrongs
Thou hast suffered from the Ursini.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: A trifle of a life , — a foolish brother
Killed in a midnight brawl. Your privilege ! ,
Your feudal privilege! ye slay our brethren,
And we—we kiss the sword. This Martin Ursini—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What of the knavish ruffian?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Mend thy phrase—
Shall ne’er be senator , —yet mend thy phrase ! ;
Bespeak him fair ! Ye ; ye may be friends.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Friends ! ?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: A day will come , when I shall see ye joined
In a close league.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Joined! by what tie?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: By Hatred hatred— hatred,
By Danger; danger— danger, the two hands that tightest grasp
Each other ; — , the two cords that soonest knit
A fast and stubborn tie . Your : your true-love knot
Is nothing to it. Faugh! the supple touch
Of pliant Interest interest , or the dust of Time time ,
Or the pin-point of Temper temper, loose , or rot ,
Or snap Love love ’s silken band. Fear and old Hate hate,
They are sure weavers ; — , they work for the storm ,
The whirlwind, and the rocking surge; their knot
Endures till death. Ye will be friends, I tell thee . — ,
Ere yon inconstant moon hath waxed and waned,
Ye will be friends. Yet Martin Ursini
Shall ne’er be senator.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Why , master prophet ,
Men say thou shalt be senator , or king,
Or emperor. Hast read the scroll? when goest thou
To head thy rebel band ? ! See! see!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: “At midnight.—”
Well, I come here to while away the time
Till that dread hour.—“Upon the Capitol.”--
Look that ye set forth scouts and men at arms
To seize sieze the chiefs, and chase the multitude,
Like sheep before the dogs. Ye were best send

To man the castle -
walls, and triply guard . —
Who is the captain of the watch?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Alberti.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Ha ! , mine old friend! I counsel ye, my lords,
Seize me, and crush this great rebellion; me ,
Cola Rienzi, honest Cola! Laugh ye?
An honest man hath played the rogue, ere now . —
Witness this scroll.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A scurvy jest!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: A jest!
Call it a jest, and ’tis a mockery
Of all that , in this worn-out world , survives
Of great and glorious ; the .—The , the eternal power
Lodged in the will of man ; , the hallowed names

Of freedom and of country!
— If a truth —

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: What , if a truth?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l:
Then—Where is Angelo
,
Crossing to Lady C.
Thy goodly son , Madonna?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Dost thou seek
A full-fledged gallantgallant: a ladies’ man, and so gaily gayly plumed,
Here , in his parent nest? If thou wouldst meet
The roverrover: a flirt or a rake, go where mandolines Mandolines are heard ,
Beneath coy Beauty’s beauty’s lattice. Count Savelli
Hath Has a fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: I have heard him praise
Bianca Ursini.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: An Ursini! —

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Calm thee, Colonna. Rest thee sure thy son
Will never stain thy honour’d name , — will never
Forget his proud obedience.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Say’st thou so?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: With a glad certainty.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Look to him , then .— ;
Yet , watch him as thou ye may, against thy your will
He shall espouse the fairest maid in Rome;
The fairest and the greatest.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: And as good
As she is great ? , and innocent as fair?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Even to the crowning of a poet’s dream ;

Gentle , and beautiful , and good.
— Yet , mark me —
Against thy will ; ! I said against thy will!

div.stage:
Exit
Rienzi
, L .

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l:
Hear’st thou ? —
Calling after Rienzi.
He’s gone . ? !

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Dear lady, think no more
Of this wild prophecy.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Nay, I am sure
Of Angelo. Why dost thou seek thy sword?
Thou goest not forth so late , good husband?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Yes . :
The night is fair . ,— I shall take horse at once
For Palestrina; thence to Avignon.
We’ll bide some struggle with these Ursini.
Will ye ride with me , kinsmen?

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: Joyfully.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: I’ll wait ye to the court. — Yet , once again ,

Beware Rienzi
. !

div.stage: Exeunt , L .

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Before the Gates of the Capitol. — The Stage darkened.
Alberti, Paolo, Citizens, &c., Crowd in the back-ground background .

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: This is the chosen spot. A brave assemblage!

sp.speaker: Second Cit.
sp.l: Why, yes. No marvel that Rienzi struck
So bold a blow. I had heard shrewd reports
Of heats, and discontents, and gathering bands,
But never dream’d of Cola.

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.l: ’Tis the spot!
Where loiters he? The night wears on apace.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: It is not yet the hour.

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: Who speaks?

sp.speaker: Another Cit.
sp.l: Alberti,
The captain of the guard; he, and his soldiers ,
Have joined our faction.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Comrades , we shall gain
An easy victory. The Ursini,
Drunk with false hope and brute debauch , feast high
Within their palace. Never wore emprise
A fairer face.

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.l: And yet the summer heaven,
Sky, moon, and stars, are over-cast overcast . The saints
Send that this darkness—

div.stage:
Enter Rienzi
from the back , C .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Darkness! did ye never
Watch the dark glooming of the thunder cloud thunder-cloud,
Ere the storm burst? We’ll light this darkness, sir,
With the brave flash of spear and sword.
Rienzi!
Live, brave Rienzi! honest Cola!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Friends! —

sp.speaker: Citizens.
sp.l: Long live Rienzi!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Listen to him.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Friends ! ,
I come not here to talk. Ye know too well
The story of our thraldom —we . We are slaves!
The bright sun rises to his course , and lights

A race of slaves!
— He sets, and his last beam
Falls on a slave: not such as, swept along
By the full tide of power, the conqueror leads
To crimson glory and undying fame;

But base ignoble slaves,
— slaves to a horde
Of petty tyrants, feudal despots , ; lords
Rich in some dozen paltry villages, —

Strong in some hundred spearmen,
— only great
In that strange spell — , a name. Each hour, dark Fraud fraud ,
Or open Rapine rapine , or protected Murder murder ,
Cry out against them. But this very day,

An honest man, my neighbour . ,—
Pointing to Paolo
, R. corner .
—there There he stands ! , —
Was struck , ,— struck like a dog, by one who wore

The badge of Ursini
, ; because, forsooth,
He tossed not high his ready cap in air,
Nor lifted up his voice in servile shouts ,
At sight of that great ruffian. Be we men ,
And suffer such dishonour? Men, and wash not
The stain away in blood? Such shames are common:
I have known deeper wrongs. I that speak to ye,
I had a brother once, a gracious boy ,
Full of all gentleness, of calmest hope, —
Of sweet and quiet joy —“there . There was the look
Of heaven upon his face, which limners give
To the beloved disciple. ” How I loved
That gracious boy , younger ! Younger by fifteen years,
Brother at once and son! ” He left my side ;
A summer bloom on his fair cheeks , ,— a smile
Parting his innocent lips ;— .” . In one short hour
The pretty harmless boy was slain! I saw
The corse, the mangled corse, and when I cried
For vengeance ! —Rouse, ye Romans!—Rouse, ye slaves!

Have ye brave sons?
— Look in the next fierce brawl

To see them die. Have ye fair daughters?
— Look
To see them live, torn from your arms, distained,
Dishonoured , ; and, if ye dare call for justice,

Be answered by the lash. Yet, this is Rome
,
That sate on her seven hills, and from her throne

Of beauty ruled the world! Yet, we are Romans
;— . !
Why , in that elder day , to be a Roman
Was greater than a king! And once again,—
Hear me , ye walls , that echoed to the tread

Of either Brutus! —
once again , I swear ,

The
Eternal City
eternal city
shall be free; her sons
Shall walk with Princes princes . Ere tomorrow’s to-morrow’s dawn ,
The tyrants—

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: Hush! Who passes there?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A foe ,
By his proud bearing. Seize him.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: As I deem,
’Tis Angelo Colonna. Touch him not, —
I would hold parley with him. Good Alberti,
The hour is nigh. Away!
Now, sir!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What be ye ,
That thus in stern and watchful mystery
Cluster beneath the veil of night, and start
To hear a stranger’s foot?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Romans.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And wherefore
Meet ye , my countrymen?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: For freedom.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Surely,
Thou art Cola di Rienzi?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Aye Ay, the voice ! ,— ,
The traitor voice ! .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I knew thee by the words.
Who, save thyself , in this bad age, when man
Lies prostrate like yon Temple temple , dared conjoin
The sounds of Rome and Freedom. freedom?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: I shall teach
The world to blend those words, as in the days
Before the Caesars. Thou shalt be the first
To hail the union. I have seen thee hang
On tales of the world’s mistress, till thine eyes
Flooded with strong emotion, have let fall
Big tear-drops on thy cheeks , and thy young hand
Hath clenched thy maiden sword — . Unsheath it now, —
Now, at thy country’s call! What ! , dost thou pause?
Is the flame quenched? Dost falter? Hence with thee,
Pass on! pass whilst thou may!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hear me, Rienzi.
Even now my spirit leaps up at the thought
Of those brave storied days , — a treasury
Of matchless visions, bright and glorified,
Paling the dim lights of this darkling world
With the golden blaze of heaven; but past and gone ,
As clouds of yesterday, as last night’s dream.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: A dream! Dost see yon phalanx, still and stern?
An hundred leaders, each with such a band,
So armed, so resolute, so fixed in will,
Wait with impatient patience suppressed impatience till they hear
The great bell of the Capitol, to spring
At once on their proud foes. Join them.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My father!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Already he hath quitted Rome.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My kinsmen!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: We are too strong for contest. Thou shalt see
No other change within our peaceful streets
Than that of slaves to freemen. Such a change
As is the silent step from night to day,
From darkness into light. We talk too long.

sp.speaker: Ang.
Rie.
sp.l: And their answer — ,
Will be the goal, the gibbet, or the axe,
And, but that I am held, amongst your great ones,
Half madman and half fool, these bones of mine
Had whitened on yon wall. Warn them! They met
At every step dark warnings. The pure air,
Where’er they passed, was heavy with the weight
Of sullen silence; friend met friend, nor smiled,
Till the last footfall of the tyrant’s steed
Had died upon the ear; and low and hoarse
Hatred came murmuring like the deep voice
Of the wind before the tempest. Sir, the boys ,— ,
The unfledged boys, march at their mothers’ hest hest, hist,

Beside their grandsires; even the girls of Rome
,— ,
The gentle and the delicate, array
Their lovers in this cause. I have one yonder — ,
Claudia Rienzi , ,— thou hast seen the maid—
A silly trembler, a slight fragile toy,
As ever nursed a dove, or reared a flower, —
Yet she, even she, is pledged—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: To whom? to whom?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: To Liberty. Was never virgin vowed
In the fair temple over right our house
To serve the goddess, Vesta, as my child
Is dedicate to Freedom. A king’s son
Might kneel in vain for Claudia. None shall wed her ,
Save a true champion of the cause.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I’ll join ye . :
How shall I swear?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Friends ! , comrades ! , countrymen!

I bring unhoped-for aid. Young Angelo
,

The immediate heir of the Colonna
, craves
To join your band.
He’s welcome!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hear me swear

By Rome
! — by freedom ! — by Rienzi! Comrades ,
How have ye titled your Deliverer deliverer ? Consul? consul— consul,
Dictator ? Emperor , emperor ?
Consul! Emperor! &c. &c.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: No . :
Those names have been so often steeped in blood,
So shamed by folly, so profaned by sin,
The sound seems ominous . ,— I’ll none of them.
My honouring duty lies.

app.rdg: The Citizens shout—Hail to our Tribune! The bell sounds thrice; shouts again; and a military band is heard playing a march without

sp.l: Hark, Hark— Ha! the bell, the bell!
The knell of tyranny , — the mighty voice ,
That , to the city and the plain , — to earth ,
And listening Heaven heaven, proclaims the glorious tale

Of Rome
reborn re-born, and Freedom. See , the clouds
Are swept away, and the moon’s boat of light
Sails in the clear blue sky, and million stars
Look out on us , and smile.
sp.stage:
The gate of the Capitol is thrown open opens, C. F., and Alberti and Soldiers join the
people
People
, and lay the keys at Rienzi’s feet.
sp.l: Hark! that great voice
Hath broke our bondage ! . Look , without a stroke
The Capitol is won ! — , the gates unfold ! — ,

The keys are at our feet ! .
Alberti
! , friend ! ,

How shall I pay thy service? —
Citizens!

First to possess the palace citadel
, —

The famous strength of Rome
, ; then to sweep on ,
Triumphant , through her streets.
sp.stage: As Rienzi and the People are entering the Capitol, he pauses.
sp.l: Oh , glorious wreck
Of gods and Caesars , ! thou shalt reign again ,
Queen of the world ! ; and I— Come come on, come on,
My people!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.l:
Live Rienzi
! Live —live our Tribune!

div.stage:
Exeunt through the gates , in the centre of the flat, into the Capitol
.

div.stage: —The Outside of a Court of Justice, R., a Crowd round the Gates . — Persons descending the Steps from time to time.

sp.stage: To the one coming down from the Steps Second Cit. , R.
sp.l: How goes the trial?

sp.speaker: Second Cit.
sp.l: Bravely.

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.stage: To the one whom he meets First Cit. in front.
sp.l: A good day fair day. !
Good neighbour ! Thou’art , thou’rt a stranger.

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: I have been
Away from Rome, good Paolo, since the day
Of our deliverance, when Rienzi punished
A servant of the Ursini, for striking
Thy bonnet from thy head.

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.l: And now thou find’st
This same Rienzi in a way to punish
The master.

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.l: The tribune
Now sits in judgment on him.

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Second Cit.
sp.l: Sir,
For a breach of the new law ; — , the mighty plunder
Of a vast wreck ; , an argosy ; — , a booty
To tempt an Emperor emperor .

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: Martin Ursini!
Almost our senator! The fearful head
Of the fearfullest name of Rome.

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.l: Aye Ay, he is like—

sp.speaker: Third Cit.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.l: — Is like to swing
From a gibbet in the Forum.

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: Will he dare?

sp.speaker: Second Cit.
sp.l: Dare! why thou saw’st his spirit . Now : now ; now his power
Matches his will; and never lineal prince
Sate firmer on his throne, or lightlier swayed
The reins of empire. He hath swept away
The oppressors and extortioners ; — , hath gained
Kingly allies ; — , hath reconciled the Pope; pope— pope,

Hath quelled the
Barons

; .
Angelo
Hath won his father to submission.

div.stage: Shouts within the court—Persons and persons come rapidly down the steps out .

sp.speaker: Pao.
sp.l: Hark!
The prisoner is condemned ? .

sp.speaker: Fourth Cit.
sp.l: He is. Rienzi
Heard him with a grave patience; almost leaning
To mercy. But the fact was flagrant.

app.rdg: More shouts and more persons passing from the court over the stage.
Persons passing from the Court of Justice over the Stage.

sp.speaker: First Cit.
sp.l: Hark!
Another shout. Where go ye?

sp.speaker: Fifth Cit.
sp.l: To the Forum,
To wait the execution.

div.stage:
Enter Rienzi, attended; and followed by Ursini, Frangipani, and other Nobles
, R. U. E .

sp.speaker: Second Cit.
sp.l: Ha, the Tribune!
And the great prisoner’s kindred.

sp.speaker: Citizens.
sp.l: Live Rienzi!
Live our just Tribune.

app.rdg: All shout when Rienzi is in the front.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Good my lord, beseech ye—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Ye plead in vain.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet hear me ! .— Force me not
To appeal against thy sentence ! .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Aye Ay ! To whom?

There stand my judges, lords, and your’s— yours: the people
,
The free and honest people! Seek of them
If I hold even the scales of justice.

sp.speaker: Citizens.
sp.l: Live
Our Tribune! our great just Tribune ! .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Follow not,

But seek Lord Angelo
. He : he hath a power
Over this haughty Despot despot .

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Gods! what tyranny
Men will endure in Freesom’s freedom’s name ! . Yes ! Yes , yes !
Lord Angelo! my foeman though he be,
His old hereditary pride will rise
Against this Churl’s churl’s base purpose. If his power—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: The Tribune holds his court at noon. Quick! Quick!

div.stage: Exeunt , R .

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: —An Apartment in the Capitol. —A couch, C.

Enter
Claudia, Berta, Teresa, and Rosa
all excepting .—All but
Claudia
occupied in embroidery and different needleworks embroidering, &c .

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Sweet lady , why so sad?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Try
Yon emerald carkanet, or let me braid
These pearls in thy long tresses.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She affects not
Such glittering baubles . Rather ; rather sing to her
One of thy songs from the cold north.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: Shall Berta
Sing to thee , lady ? .

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes . , I care not.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Sing.

div.stage: Song.—

sp.speaker: Berta.
sp.l: The red-rose is Queen red rose is queen of the garden bower ,
That glows in the sun at noon;
And the lady lily’s the fairest flower
That swings her white bells in the breeze of June;
But they who come ’mid frost and flood,
Peeping from bank , or root of tree,
The primrose and the violet bud violet-bud,—
They are the dearest flowers to me.
The nightingale’s is the sweetest song
That ever the rose hath heard;
And when the lark sings, the white clouds among ,
The lily looks up to the heavenly bird . :
But the robin, with his eye of jet,
Who pipes from the bare boughs merrily ,
To the primrose pale and the violet, —
His is the dearest song to me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Didst like the strain?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There’s a deep wisdom in it . :
The lowly blossom, and the wintery friend ,— ,
They are the dearest. I’m set i’ the sun
To wither.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.l: She is sad again. Wouldst hear
A merry story, lady? ” Or a tale of murder
Of murder to To divert thee ?” ?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Or a legend

Fresh from the
holy land
Holy Land
?

div.stage:
Enter Rienzi
, L .

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: The Tribune!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Leave us.

app.rdg: The ladies rise to go out, R.

sp.l:
“
Claudia
! —nay, start not! —
Thou art sad to-day . ;
I found thee sitting idly, ’midst thy maids —
A pretty , laughing , restless band, who plied
Quick tongue and nimble finger .” Mute , mute , and pale
As marble ; , those unseeing unseeming eyes were fixed
As sternly , as if the rude stranger , Thought , —
Age-giving, mirth-destroying, pitiless Thought ,
Had knocked at thy young giddy brain.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, father,
Mock not thine own poor Claudia.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Claudia used
To bear a merry heart, with that clear voice ,
Prattling , ; and that light busy foot , astir
In her small housewifery, the blythest blithest bee
That ever wrought in hive.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh ! mine old home!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: What ails thee , lady-bird?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Mine own dear home!
Father , I love not this new state; these halls ,
Where comfort dies in vastness; these trim maids ,
Whose service wearies me. Oh ! mine old home!
My quiet, pleasant chamber, with the myrtle
Woven round the casement , ; and the cedar by ,
Shading the sun; my garden overgrown
With flowers and herbs, thick-set as grass in fields;
My pretty snow-white doves; my kindest nurse ;
And old Camillo.—Oh ! mine own dear home!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Why , simple child, thou hast thine old fond nurse,
And good Camillo, and shalt have thy doves,
Thy myrtles, flowers, and cedars , ; a whole province

" Laid in a garden, an ’ thou wilt. My Claudia
,
Hast thou not learnt thy power? Ask orient gems ,
Diamonds , and sapphires , in rich caskets, wrought
By cunning goldsmiths; sigh for rarest birds,
Of farthest Ind, like winged flowers, to flit
Around thy stately bower; and, at a wish,
The precious toys shall wait thee. " Old Camillo!

Thou shalt have nobler servants , —
Emperors, Kings emperors, kings,
Electors, Princes princes ! not a bachelor
In christendom Christendom but would right proudly kneel,
To my fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh! mine own dear home!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Wilt have a list to chuse choose from? Listen, sweet!
If the tall cedar, and the branchy myrtle,
And the white doves, were tell tales tell-tales , I would ask them
Whose was the shadow on the sunny wall?
And if , at eventide , they heard not oft
A tuneful mandoline, and then a voice,
Clear in its manly depth, whose tide of song
O’erwhelmed the quivering instrument , ; and then
A world of whispers , mixed with low response,
Sweet , short , and broken, as divided strains
Of nightingales ? .

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh , father! father!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Well!

Dost Do’st love him ,
Claudia?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Father!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Dost Do’st thou love
Young Angelo? Yes? Saidst thou yes? That heart — ,
That throbbing heart of thine , keeps such a coil,
I cannot hear thy words. He is returned

To Rome
. ; he left thee on mine errand, dear-one. dear one; dear one:
And now—Is there no casement myrtle-wreathed casement-myrtle wreathed ,
No cedar in our courts , to shade tonight to-night
The lover’s song?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh , father! father!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Now ,
Back to thy maidens , with a lightened heart ,
Mine own beloved child. Thou shalt be first

In Rome
, as thou art fairest . Never Princess ; never princess
Brought to the proud Colonna such a dower
As thou. Young Angelo hath chosen his mate
From out an Eagle’s eagle’s nest.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Alas! alas!
I tremble at the height. Whene’er I think

Of the hot
Barons
barons
, of the fickle people,
And the inconstancy of power, I tremble
For thee, dear Father father .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Tremble! Let them tremble.

I am their master ,
Claudia
. Whom , whom they scorned,
Endured, protected . —Sweet , go dream of love .!--.

I am their master ,
Claudia.

div.stage: Exeunt , R .

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A Magnificent Hall in the Capitol.

Enter Colonna, R.,
Ursini, Frangipani, Cafarello, the Nuncio, an Ambassador, Nobles, &c. , R. and L.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Gibbet and cord! a base plebeian death!
And he the head of the great Roman name,

That rivalled the Colonna! Ursini
,

The shame is general. How say ye
Barons
, barons
?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: If ye resist, ye share his doom. Plead! plead!
Dissemble with the tyrant, — stifle hate,
And master scorn , as I have done. Plead! plead! Plead for him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: To Cola! Can I frame my speech to sue

To Cola
. Most —most , most familiar of the drones
That thronged my hall of afternoons, content
To sit below the salt, and bear all jests ; ,— ,
The retinue and pest of greatness. Sue
To Cola!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Fear not , but revenge will come,
We being friends, from whose dissension sprang
The usurper’s strength. An hour will come.
Lord Angelo,
Thou wilt not fail us ? .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Surely, no . ’Tis ! ’tis ! ’Tis stern,

Revengeful, cruel, pitiless . ! The people
! — ,

To soothe the fickle people
! Yet —yet he’s wiser:
He’ll be persuaded.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He approaches.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What!
Ushered with music as a king.

div.stage:
Enter Rienzi
— , R., , attended.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Why , this
Is well, my lords, this full assemblage. Now
The chief of Rome stands fitly girt with names
Strong as their towers around him. Fall not off,
And we shall be impregnable.
Lord Nuncio,

I should have asked ask’d
your thy blessing. I have sent

Our missives missions to the
Pontiff
pontiff
. Count Savelli
— ,—
My lord ambassador , I crave your pardon , .

What news from Venice, the Sea-Queen sea-queen ? —
Savelli,
I have a little maiden who must know

Thy fairest daughter. Angelo
! ,
Colonna
! ,
A double welcome! Rome lacked half her state
Wanting her princely Columns.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Sir, I come

A suitor to you. thee.— thee.
Martin Ursini—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: When last his name was on thy lips . —Well, sir,
Thy suit ! , thy suit! If pardon, take at once
My answer . —No.

app.rdg: Crosses to Angelo, in R. corner.—Colonna goes up.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yet , mercy—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Waste not thy pleadings on a desperate cause
And a resolved spirit. She awaits thee.
Haste to that fairer court.
My Lord Colonna,
This is a needful justice.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Noble Tribune,
It is a crime which custom—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Aye Ay , the law
Of the strong against the weak , — your law, the law
Of the sword and spear. But, gentles, ye live now
Under the good Estate estate .

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: He is noble — .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Therefore,
A thousand times he dies. Ye are noble, sirs,
And need a warning.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Sick , almost to death — .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Ye have less cause to grieve.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: New-wedded — .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Madonna Laura is a blooming dame ,
And will become her weeds.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: Remember, Tribune ,
He hath two uncles, cardinals. Wouldst outrage
The sacred college?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: The lord cardinals,
Meek , pious , lowly men , and loving virtue,
Will render thanks to him , who wipes a blot
So flagrant from their name.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: An Ursini!
Head of the Ursini!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Mine only brother!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: And dar’st darest talk thou to me of brothers? Thou ,
Whose groom—wouldst have me break my own just laws ,
To save thy brother? Thine thine ! Hast thou forgotten
When that most beautiful and blameless boy,
The prettiest piece of innocence that ever
Breathed Breath’d in this sinful world, lay at thy feet,
Slain by thy pampered minion, and I knelt
Before thee for redress, whilst thou— Didst didst never
Pure justice ; , not revenge . !— Mark well, my lords, —
Pure equal justice. Martin Ursini
Had open trial, is guilty, is condemned,
And he shall die . !

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Yet listen to us—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Lords,
If ye could range before me all the peers ,
Prelates , and potentates of Christendom, —
The Holy Father holy pontiff kneeling at my knee,
And Emperors emperors crouching at my feet , to sue
For this great robber, still I should be blind
As justice. But this very day a wife,
One infant hanging at her breast, and two ,
Scarce bigger, first-born twins of misery,
Clinging to the poor rags that scarcely hid
Her squalid form, grasped at my bridle rein bridle-rein
To beg her husband’s life , ; condemned to die
And , whilst the fiery war-horse chaf’d and reared,
Shaking his crest, and plunging to get free,
There, midst the dangerous coil , unmov’d , she stood ,
Pleading in piercing broken words, and long shrill screams and piercing shrieks ,
And hoarse low shivering sobs, the very cry
Of nature! And, when I at last said No no —
For I said No no to her ! —she flung herself
And those poor innocent babes between the stones
And my hot Arab’s hoofs. We sav’d them all, —

Thank Heaven heaven
, we saved them all! But but I said No no
To that sad woman , midst her shrieks. Ye dare not
Ask me for mercy now.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Yet he is noble!
Let him not die a felon’s death . :

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Again ! ,

Ye weary me. No more of this. Colonna
,
Thy son loves my fair daughter. ’Tis an union,
However my young Claudia might have graced
A monarch’s side, that augurs hopefully , —
Bliss to the wedded pair, and peace to Rome,
" And it shall be accomplished. Good , my lords,
I bid ye to the bridal; one and all,
I bid ye to the bridal feast. And now
A fair good morrow . !

div.stage:
Exit ;
Rienzi
, R., attended by the
Nuncio
, Ambassador and other Lords, &c.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Hath stern destiny
Clothed him in this man’s shape, that , in a breath ,
He deals out death and marriage? Ursini!
Colonna! be ye stunned?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I’ll follow him!
Tyrant! usurper! base-born churl! to deem
That son of mine—

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Submit , as I have done ,
For vengeance. From our grief and shame shall spring
A second retribution; and this banquet, —
This nuptial banquet, this triumphal hour ,
Shall be the very scene of our revenge . !
I may not loiter here. The fatal moment

Of our disgrace is nigh.
— Ere evening close ,
I’ll seek thee at thy palace. Seem to yield ,
And Victory victory is sure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I’ll take thy counsel.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage:
—A Hall in the Capitol —a Chair of State, L. S. E. —The Tribune’s Crimson Chair, elevated on two Steps , R. S. E.—
a splendid Banquet, Lords and Ladies seated round the Tables , up the C .

Enter
Savelli, Frangipani
, and Cafarello
in , L., who advance to the front—Camillo and other Attendants in the background , R .

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: He bears him like a Prince; prince, save that he lacks
The port serene of majesty. His mood
Is fitful; stately now , and sad; anon ,
Full of a hurried mirth; courteous awhile ,
And mild; then bursting , on a sudden , forth ,
Into sharp biting taunts.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And at the altar ,
When he first found the proud and angry mother

Refused to grace the nuptials, even the
Nuncio
nuncio
Quailed at his fiery threats.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: I saw Colonna
Gnawing his lip for wrath.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Why , this new power
Mounts to the brain like wine. For such disease ,
Your skilful leech lets blood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Suspects he aught
Of our design? we hunt a subtle quarry.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: But with a wilier huntsman.
Hath every point been guarded? be the masquers
Valiant and strongly armed? have ye ta’en order
To close the gates , — to seize his train , — to cut
The cordage of the bell, that none may summon
The people to his rescue?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: All is cared for,
And vengeance certain. Before set of sun ,

We shall be masters of ourselves, of Rome
,
And Rome’s proud ruler. This quaint masque of our’s ours —

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: What is the watch-word watchword ?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Death.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Peace ! , peace ! — he comes!

app.rdg: Frangipani, Cafarello, and Savelli, retire up

div.stage:
Enter Angelo, Claudia
, and Ladies , R . —As Angelo leads in Claudia, followed by two Ladies, all the visitors to the banquet rise, and curtsy to Claudia, who returns it, and remains conversing with the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No, ’tis the blooming bride. Young Angelo
Hath no ill choice in beauty.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: ’Tis a maid
Shy as a ringdove ring-dove . See , how delicate,
How gentle, yet how coy! Poor pretty fool! foo fool,
No harm must happen her.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: None, none.

div.stage: Angelo advances to them.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: Good kinsman ,
I would not have thee hear Savelli speak
Of thy fair bride.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Ah! Doth doth he praise her? Lords,

Beseech ye sit.
Lords and Ladies sit down.
Savelli
, I would fain
Make of thy daughter and my blushing wife
A pair of lovely friends. Look where they stand ,
The fairest two in Rome.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: The Tribune comes.

div.stage:
Enter Rienzi
, R., and Colonna
, .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Where lags our hostess? Take thy state , fair bride , —
" Thy one day’s Queen-ship queenship . See , the nuptial wreath
Sits crown like crown-like on thy brow; thy nuptial robe
Flows royally. Come, come, be gracious! Bid
A smiling welcome to the subject world.
Thou art a Colonna. Wouldst thou be the first
Of that proud name to ape the peasant’s virtue ,
Humility? Fie! Fie fie !

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Sir , the Colonna—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay, good my father, sure to day to-day our name
Hath cause of pride.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Heaven grant it prove so!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Lady ,
Thou art silent still.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Shall I speak for thee , love?
Oh, weak and ineffectual were my words ,
Matched with thy burning blush, thy quivering smile ,

Thy conscious silence ,
Claudia
. !— Gentle friends ,
Ye are nobly welcome.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: This is well , fair son!
Yet we lack mirth. Have ye no masque astir , ?
No dance, no music, no quaint mystery,
To drive away the spectre Thought. , thought? , Thought? A bridal
Is but a gilt and painted funeral
To the fond father who hath yielded up
His one sweet child. Claudia, thy love , thy duty ,
Thou hast a master now; and I have thrown
My precious pearl away. Yet men , who give
A living daughter to the fickle will
Of a capricious bridegroom , laugh , —the madmen! —
Laugh at the jocund bridal feast ; , and weep
When the fair corse is laid in blessed rest ,
Deep , deep in mother earth. Oh , happier far ,
So to have lost my child!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Father!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Thou hast gained
A son, not lost a daughter.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Love her, Angelo;
Cherish her ; , love her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: More than life.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Bring mirth , —
Music , and dance , and song, and I will laugh,
And chase away these images of death
That float afore mine eyes. A song ! A —a , a song!

app.rdg: Sits down in the Chair of State

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have named the masque.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Better anon.
Hail to the gentle bride! the Dove dove
High-nested High nested in the Column’s crest,— column’s crest!
Oh , welcome , as the bird of love ,
Who bore the olive sign olive-sign of rest!

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Hail to the bride!
Hail to the gentle bride! the Flower flower
Whose garlands round the Column twine;— column twine!
Oh , fairer than the citron bower!
More fragrant than the blossomed blossom’d vine!

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Hail to the bride!
Hail to the gentle bride! the star
Whose radiance o’er the column beams!
Oh , soft as moonlight , seen afar ,
A silver shine on trembling streams!

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Hail to the bride!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: A pleasant strain!
sp.stage: A Citizen rushes from amongst the Attendants, and presents a paper to Rienzi.
sp.l: What wouldst thou , friend?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: May it please thee
To read this scroll , great Tribune.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Can the Daemon daemon
To whom his soul is pledged have ta’en this way

To show our secret?
— No . He , he smiles! he smiles!

His hand shakes not!
— I breathe again.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Fair sir ,
All thou hast asked is granted.
’Tis no day
To frown on a petition. Mirth , my lords ! ,— ,
Bring Mirth! I brook no pause of revelry.
Have ye no masque?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: He rushes in the toils;
Now weave the meshes round him.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Sooth, my lord,
We had plotted to surprise the gentle bride

With a slight dance,
— a toy, an antic.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: And when?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Soon as the bell tolled four, the masquers were bid to enter.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Four? And how attired?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Turbaned and robed Turban’d and rob’d, and with swart visages ;
A troop of lusty Moors.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Admit these revellers— Mark me . —

div.stage:
Gives orders in a low voice to Camillo
, and also the paper which he has just received from the Citizen .

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Now , vengeance , thou art mine!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Wine ! Wine —wine !

app.rdg: The Attendant fills a goblet, and presents it to Rienzi.

sp.l:
Fill high, my noble guests : .
Claudia Rienzi,
And Angelo Colonna! Blest Bless’d be they
And we in their fair union! Doubly curst curs’d
Who’er in wish or thought would loose that tie
Fill high the mantling wine, and in the bowl
Be all unkindness buried . !

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Heartily
We pledge you , noble Tribune.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Why, Colonna!

Brother!
—
Colonna rises.
He startles at the word ; he . He eyes
The cup as it were poisoned. Dost thou think

We’ve drugged the draught? I’ll be thy taster.
— Drink!
The wine is honest . We’re —we’re ! We’re no traitors!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Drink . ! ?
I prythee pr’ythee, drink . !

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Health to the gentle bride!
Health to my children!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l:
Noble Colonna
; , this is princely. Now ,
If any scorn thee, Claudia, say Colonna,
Whose word is truth, hailed thee his child.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My lords
And kinsmen all, if a poor simple maid,
And yet Rienzi’s daughter, so may dare
To call ye, take my thanks. On every head
Be every fair wish trebled. Gentle friends—

div.stage: Rises to go, attended by Angelo, and followed by the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Wilt thou not wait the masque?
sp.stage: Exeunt Claudia, Angelo, and Ladies , R .
sp.l:
Thou wilt not.
— Well!

We must carouse the deeper. " Hark ,
Francesco!
Go bid the fountains , from their marble mouths ,
Pour the rich juice of the Sicilian grape,
A flood of molten rubies, that our kind
And drouthy fellow citizens fellow-citizens may chorus
Hail to the gentle bride. I would fain bid
Old Tyber Tiber flow with wine. " Another cup —

To thee and thine ,
Colonna! Fill fill the bowl ,
Higher and higher! Let the phantom , fear , —

And doubt , that haunts sound princes, —
and suspicion,

That broods a Harpy harpy o’er the banquet,
— flee
Down to the uttermost depths of Hell hell . A health

To thee and thine ,
Colonna!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Of what doubt
Speaks our great Tribune?

sp.speaker: Rie.

app.rdg: Enter the Masquers at different sides.

sp.l:
Doubt!
— Spake I of doubt?

Fear!
— Said I fear?
— So fenced around by friends,
Allies , and kinsmen, what have I to fear

From treason , or from traitors?
— Say yon band

Were rebels, ye would guard me!
— Call them murderers,
Ye would avenge me ? . !

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Aye Ay , by death.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: And thou?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: By death!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Seize the foul traitors. Ye have passed
sp.stage:
To the Masquers, who seize the Nobles
, &c.
sp.l: Your own just sentence. Yield, my masters ; , yield . !
Your men are overpowered; your masquers chained;
The courts are lined with guards ; , and at one stroke , —
One touch upon this bell, the strength of Rome,
All that hath life within her the walls, will rise
To crush ye. Yield your swords. Do ye not shame

To wear them?
— Yield your swords.

div.stage:
Re-enter Angelo
, R .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Rienzi!
sp.stage: Then to one of the Guards, who seizes Colonna.
sp.l: Villain !

An thou but touch the Lord Colonna
—aye, —ay, , ay,
An thou but dare to lay thy ruffian hand
Upon his garment—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Seize his sword.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Again!

Art frenetic ,
Rienzi?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Seek of them.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Father , in mercy , speak! Give me a cause , ;
And , though a legion hemmed thee in, thy son
Should rescue thee. Speak but one word, dear father,
Only one word! Sure as I live, thou art guiltless;
Sure as the sun tracks his bright path in Heaven heaven ,

Thy course is pure.
— Yet speak!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: He is silent.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Speak.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l:
Thou know’st them, Angelo
—: :— the bold Savelli,

The Frangipani
, and the Ursini,—

Aye Ay , and the high Colonna
. Well ; well thou knowest
Each proud and lofty visage . Mark ;—mark them, now . :
They should be signed as Cain of old, for Guilt , —
Detected, baffled, murderous Guilt, hath set
His bloody hand upon them. Son, thou shudderest . !
Their tawny masquers should have slain me; here ,
Here in my festive hour ; — ,— the mutual cup
Sparkling; the mutual pledge half spoke; the bread,
Which we have broke together, unconsumed
Sinful and unconfessed , ;— ; so had I fallen — ;
And so— The the word was Death. death.— death! From their own lips
Came their own righteous sentence—Death . !

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh, mercy!

Mercy!
— Thou liv’st.
— ’Twas but the intent—

rdg.del: Were nothing; but through me the traitors struck

app.rdg: Were nothing; but, through me, the traitors struck

rdg.del: At peace, at liberty, at Rome, my country

app.rdg: At peace, at liberty, at Rome

rdg.del: Bright and regenerate, the world’s mistress once,

app.rdg: Bright and regenerate, the world’s mistress once,

rdg.del: And doomed like the old fabled bird to rise

app.rdg: And doomed, like the old fabled bird, to rise

rdg.del: Strong from her ashes. Did ye think the people

app.rdg: Strong from her ashes. Did ye think the people

rdg.del: Could spare their Tribune? Did ye deem them weary

app.rdg: Could spare their Tribune? Did ye deem them weary

rdg.del: Of equal justice and mild law and freedom

app.rdg: Of equal justice; and mild law; and freedom

rdg.del: As liberal as the air and mighty fame

app.rdg: As liberal as the air; and mighty fame,

rdg.del: A more resplendant sun? Sirs I am guarded

app.rdg: A more resplendant sun? Sirs, I am guarded

rdg.del: By the invisible shield of love which blunts

app.rdg: By the invisible shield of love, which blunts

rdg.del: The darts of treachery. I cannot die

app.rdg: The darts of treachery. I cannot die,

rdg.del: Whilst Rome commands me live. For ye foul traitors

app.rdg: Whilst Rome commands me, live. For ye, foul traitors,

rdg.del: I pardon ye, and I despise ye. Go!

app.rdg: I pardon ye, and I despise ye.

rdg.del: Ye are free.

app.rdg: They who are sent, one in a thousand years,
To renovate old empires, and to bid
Cities once famous, like the fabled bird
Rise stronger from their ashes—they, the few
The chosen, the peculiar, tread in the light
Of their own peculiar star the glorious path
Of destiny. My death! Ye might as soon
Aim your dark bolts at that bright star; I soar
Too high above ye. Sirs! I cannot die
Whilst Fame commands me live. For ye foul traitors
I pardon ye and despise ye. Go!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh , thanks , my father.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Said he thanks?
Chains ! , bring me chains! such words from such a tongue
Were slavery worse than death. Chains! chains! —Chains—Chains—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Ye are free.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Is the proud pillar of Colonna fallen ,
That base plebeian feet bestride its shaft?
Is Ursini’s strong bear muzzled and chained ,
That every cur—

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: The Tribune means us fairly.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Still ye are free. —

Yet mark me, signors:
— Tame your rebel bloods ;
Be faithful subjects to the Good Estate good estate ;
Demolish your strong towers, which overtop
Our beautiful city with barbarian pride,
Loosing fell rapine , discord , and revenge,
From out their dens accurst accurs’d . Be quiet subjects,
And ye shall find the State state a gentle mistress ; — .
Else—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Doth he threaten?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Hush! this is no time . ,—
An hour will come ! —

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: What ! Do , do you mutter , traitors?
Follow me instant to the Lateran.
There , at the holy altar, with such rites ,
As to profane were sin more damnable
Than treason ever dared, to offer up

Your vowed allegiance to freed free’d
Rome,
— to me ,

Her servant, minister, deliverer,
— me ,
Your master. Ye are free; but I will chain
Your rebel souls with oaths. Follow me , sirs.

div.stage: Exeunt , R .

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: The Capitoline Hill.

Enter Ursini and Frangipani
, R .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay, Ursini, why pluck me by the sleeve?

Why steal from the procession?
— Why reawaken
The tyrant’s anger?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: For revenge . !— ! Ye are stunned,
Bewildered , as men rousing from a dream ,
That know not where they stand. Dost thou not see
Our great revenge is sure? The tyrant walks
Blinded by his vain-glory vain glory ; confident
In that straw fetter, an extorted oath;

app.rdg: And we—Why are we not resolved? And be not
Our bold retainers waiting armed in proof,
Why are we not resolved? And be not
Our bold retaineers waiting, armed in proof,
Without the gates of Rome? What if tonight—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This very hour ! our . Our tried and hardy band,
Led by the chivalry of Rome, could carry

The city at a charge . Nay ; and
Rome herself
Will rise against the madman.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Here comes one,
Whose name were worth a host. Didst thou not mark ,
How, stung by the sharp scorn Rienzi flung
On proud Colonna, the young bridegroom broke
From his new father’s side?
Lord Angelo,
A truant from this pageant?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: As thou see’st.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet , thy good father, our great Tribune—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sir,
I am a son of the Colonna.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: The heir of that most princely house . And ; and, sir,
Fair though she be, a friend must frankly wish
She owned another sire.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l:
No more!
— no more!
How passed pass’d the ceremonial , Count? Beseech ye thee,
Tell us of these new rites.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: The noble train
Rolled smoothly on. Rienzi led the band
Right royally ; , sceptered and robed , and backing
A milk white milk-white Arab, whose bright from whose eyeballs flashed
Intolerable fire Quick gleams of glittering light . Colonna held
The bridle rein bridle-rein .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l:
Stephen Colonna
? !

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l:
Thy father , sir. We meaner
Barons
barons
walked
Behind, bareheaded, and with folded arms,
As men doing penance , to the holy shrine
Of St. John Lateran. Then came a mummery
Of oaths to that indefinite she, the State—
Republic, sir, is out of date—and then—

sp.speaker: Caf.
Sav.
sp.l: Then Rienzi,
Stepping before the altar, his bold hand
Laid on the consecrated Host, sent forth,
In a full pealing voice, that rolled along
The fretted roof , like the loud organ-swell,
A rash and insolent summons to the Pope
And Cardinals; next he cited to appear

The imperial rivals ,
Charles and Lewis; next,
The Electors Palatine. Then, whilst the aisles
Of the hushed church prolonged his words, he drew
His dazzling sword, and , waving the bright blade
To the four points of Heaven, cried with a deep
Intensity of will , that drove his words

Like arrows through the brain,
—" This, too, is mine ! .”
Yes ! , to each part of this fair earth he cried ,—
" Thou , too , art mine ! .”

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Madman! And ye ? —

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: We listened
In patience and in silence , ; whilst he stood
His form dilating, and his haughty glance
Instinct with fiery pride.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now, by St. John,
Had I been there , ye should have heard a voice
Answer this frenzied summoner.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Our answer
Is yet unspoken. Angelo Colonna,
If the old glories of thy princely race,
Thy knightly honour, thy fresh budding fresh-budding fame ,
Outshine the red and white of Claudia’s cheek,
Then—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Wherefore pause? I know thee, Ursini, —
Rienzi’s mortal foe, and scarce a friend

To the Colonna
. Yet ;—yet, ; yet, in honour’s name —
Say on . !

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Lead home the steed. I’ll walk from hence.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Meet me at the Colonna Palace. Fail not.

div.stage: Enter Rienzi, attended by Colonna, and others other Lords , L .

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Ah! he is here . Son—ye .—Son! Ye !—Son! Ye may leave us, lords, —
We are content with your good service .
Son,
sp.stage:
Exeunt all but Rienzi and Angelo
. ,
sp.l: Methinks this high solemnity might well
Have claimed thy presence. A great ruler’s heir
Should be familiar in the people’s eyes;
Win woman’s smiles by honest courtesy,
And force man’s tardier praise by bold desert:
So, when the chief shall die, the general voice love
May hail his successor. But thou —Where , where wast thou?
If with thy bride—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l:
I have not seen her.
— Tribune , —
Thou wav’st away the word with such a scorn

As I poured poison in thine ear.
— Already
Dost weary of the title?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Wherefore should I?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Thou art ambitious.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Granted.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And wouldst be
A king.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l:
There thou mistak’st.
— A king! Fair Son fair son! Fair Son,
Power dwelleth not in sound, and fame hath garlands
Brighter than diadems. I might have been
Anointed, sceptered, crowned ; , have cast a blaze
Of glory round the old imperial wreath ,
The laurel of the Caesars; but I chose
To master kings, not to be one; " to direct
The royal puppets as my sovereign will ,

And Rome
— , my Rome
, decree.
— Tribune! the Gracchi

Were called so. ”--
Tribune! I will make that name

A word of fear to
Kings
kings
.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Rienzi! Tribune!
Hast thou forgotten , on this very spot ,
How thou didst shake the slumbering soul of Rome
With the brave sound of Freedom freedom , till she rose,
And from her giant limbs the shackles dropt dropped,
Burst by one mighty throe? Hadst thou died then ,
History had crowned thee with a glorious title —
Deliverer of thy country.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Well ? !

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Alas!
When now thou fall’st, as fall thou must, ’twill be

The common tale of low ambition.
— Tyrants
O’erthrown to form a wilder tyranny;
Princes cast down , that thy obscurer house
May rise on nobler ruins.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Hast thou ended?
I fain would have mistaken thee . Hast —hast done?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No . For ; for, despite thy smothered wrath, the voice
Of warning truth shall reach thee. Thou to day to-day
Hast , by thy frantic sacrilege , drawn on thee
The thunders of the church, the mortal feud

Of either Emperor emperor . Here , at home , the
Barons
barons
Hate, and the people shun thee. Seest thou not ,
Even in this noon of pride , thy waning power
Fade, flicker, and wax dim ? . Thou art as one
Perched on some lofty steeple’s dizzy height,
Dazzled by the sun, inebriate by long draughts
Of thinner air , ; too giddy to look down
Where all his safety lies , ; too proud to dare
The long descent to the low depths from whence
The desperate climber rose.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Aye Ay , there’s the sting ! ,—
That I, an insect of to-day, outsoar

The reverend worm , nobility . !
Wouldst Would’st shame me
With my poor parentage ? !— ! Sir, I’m the son
Of him who kept a sordid hostelry
In the Jews’ quarter . ; my good mother cleansed

Linen for honest hire.
— Canst thou say worse?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Can worse be said?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Add , that my boasted schoolcraft
Was gained from such base toil, gained with such pain
That the nice nurture of the mind was oft ,
Stolen at the body’s cost. I have gone dinnerless
And supperless, the scoff of our poor street ,
For tattered vestments and lean hungry looks,
To pay the Pedagogue. pedagogue.— pedagogue. Add what thou wilt
Of injury. Say that , grown into man ,
I’ve known the pittance of the hospital,
And, more degrading still, the patronage
Of the Colonna. Of the tallest trees
The roots delve deepest. Yes ! , I’ve trod thy halls,
Scorned and derided midst their ribald crew,
A licensed Jester jester , save the cap and bells ; :
I have borne this , — and I have borne the death,
The unavenged death , of a dear brother.
I seemed , I was , a base ignoble slave.

What am I?
— Peace ! , I say . What !—what am I now?
In all but name , her sovereign; last of all ,
Thy father.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: In an evil hour—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Dar’st thou
Say that? An evil hour for thee ! , my Claudia!
Thou shouldst have been an Emperor’s emperor’s bride , my Fairest fairest .
In evil hour thy woman’s heart was caught ,
“ By the form moulded as an antique god , ;” ;
The gallant bearing, the feigned tale of love . — ,
All false, all outward , simulated all.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: But that I loved her, but that I do love her ,
With a deep tenderness, softer and fonder
Than thy ambition-hardened heart ere dreamt e’er dream’d of,
My sword should answer thee.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l:
Go to , Lord Angelo
;

Thou lov’st her not.
— Men taunt not , nor defy
The Dear-one’s dear one’s kindred. A bright atmosphere
Of sunlight and of beauty breathes around

The bosom’s idol.
— I have lov’d . She —she loves thee;

And therefore thy proud father,
— even the shrew,
Thy railing mother , in her eyes , are sacred.
Lay not thy hand upon thy sword , fair son ; — ,
Keep that brave for thy comrades ; . I’ll not fight thee.
Go , and give thanks to yonder simple bride ,
That her plebeian father mews not up ,
Safe in the citadel , her noble husband.

Thou art dangerous ,
Colonna. But , for her — , ,—
Beware!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l:
Come back ,
Rienzi! Thus I throw
A brave defiance in thy teeth.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Once more , .
Beware!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Take up the glove . !

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: This time, for her , —
For her dear sake . Home —come to thy bride! Home home ! home!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Dost fear me, Tribune tribune of the People? people!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Fear!

Do I fear thee ? !— Tempt me no more.
— This once — ,
Home to thy bride . !

div.stage: Exit , R .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now, Ursini, I come — ,
Fit partner of thy vengeance !

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A Hall in the Colonna Palace.

Carafello Enter Ursini, Stephen
Colonna, Lady Colonna, Savelli, Frangipani, &c and Nobles , R .

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Five thousand horsemen at the gates of Rome,
And armed retainers in each house, and knights
Harnessed Harness’d in glittering mail , ; with banner proud ,
And trump , and war-cry, hurling their bright spears
At the usurper’s ursurper’s head! Why , now I know ye ,

My gallant kinsmen.
— When ye crouched , like hounds ,
Beneath the tyrant’s lash; or stealthily ,
At midnight meetings , and below your breath ,
Muttered Mutter’d of murders ,— — , the quick poinard-stroke , —
The calculated poison , that consumes
So much of life aday, a day— a day, or that mute slayer,
The Eastern bow-string ,— , Chivalry chivalry of Rome,
What marvel that I knew ye not, distained
With such base purpose. Now ye have clothed death
In the brave guise of War war , and made him gay
And lovely as a bridegroom . Speed , speed ye forth!
Away! the sun is low . !— Ye have a city
To win , ere night . !

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Better await the night ;
And then, in darkness and in storm, at once
Crush the stunned stunn’d Tribune.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Dost thou say await ,
Stephen Colonna? Dost thou seek the veil

Of darkness for a deed of light?
— On ! , on!
Whilst yet the sunbeams kiss the glittering stream

Of armed knights and barbed steeds.
— On ! , on!
Whilst yet the columned column’d banners of our house
May catch their parting glory, as the peaks

Of highest Alps
shine oer shine o’er the twilight world.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: The lady counsels well. In every street
Stand knots of citizens in sad debate
Of their proud ruler’s frenzy . ; I have sent
Bold tongues amongst them, madam—

div.stage:
Enter Angelo
, L .

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Lo , ! thy son!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Sir, since he called Rienzi’s daughter wife,
I have no son . !

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh, mother, say not so!

Savelli
, !
Ursini
, ! ye bade me hither
With broken phrase and solemn tone, and pause
Of mighty import. Good my lords , I come
To read your mystery. The city’s full
Of camp-like noises; tramp of steeds, and clash
Of mail, and trumpet blast trumpet-blast , and ringing clang
Of busy armourers . ; the grim bandog ban-dog bays;
The champing war-horse in his stall neighs loud;
The vulture shrieks aloft. Ye are still leagued
Against Rienzi.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Wouldst betray—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Betray!
Why , I am spurned, derided, scorned, cast off ,
As a child’s broken toy . , Betray! I come
To join ye ;—Aye . Ay , dear mother !— , to pull down
The haughty tyrant from his throne, or fall
As may beseem thy son. Angels and saints ,

Bear witness to my
truth. oath! oath

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.l: I do believe thee
With a most constant faith. On thy clear brow
Honour and Victory victory sit crowned.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh, put me
To the proof, my lords! Why stay we here good ? Good father ? ,
Think’st thou Suspicion’s suspicion’s straining eye-balls sleep ? ,
Or that the watcher , Doubt doubt , hath lost her keen
And delicate sense of sound? We must forerun
The Tyrant’s tyrant’s fear. Follow me , ye , that love
The joy of glorious battle . !

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Angelo!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l:
Nay, when the fight is won.
— Then thou shalt dew

My laurels with glad tears.
— Stay me not now.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Bear to the fight thy mother’s blessing, boy , —
Her proud and joyful blessing, not her tears.

Thou art the last of all my children ,
Angelo
, —
Dearest and last. Unkindness never came
Betwixt us twain save once. But , had I sons
As many and as brave as that old queen
Who mourned her Troy in ashes, I would peril
Each several warrior in this cause as freely
As thou , my one fair boy. Now speed thee forth ,

To conquest or to death.
— Why lingerest thou ,
My Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Mother!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: What wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Claudia!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: His daughter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Poor , poor Claudia! I have left her
Even on our bridal day bridal-day . But, if I fall —
Mother!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.l: Fie! fie Fie ! his daughter! speed thee forth

To battle!
— On, brave kinsmen!

div.stage: Exeunt , L .

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: An Apartment in the Capitol.

Enter
Rienzi
, L., and Claudia
, R. , meeting , C .

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Father!
At last I find thee , father!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Well, my child , !
What wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay , I know not. Be the guests
Departed?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: All gone ! ; and wherefore loiters— went ye

app.rdg: To the Lateran, dear father? And where loiters—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Aspic!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Methought a bridal should be merrier , —
Not merrier , but happier. Angelo!

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Oh , foulest ingrate! when I wed thy mother—
Oh , fiend accurst accurs’d !

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay ; , nay . Perchance ,—perchance he’s gone
To crave his mother’s blessing. Is’t not strange
That I should love so well who loves not me?
But I have felt a yearning of the heart
Toward that majestic lady, which hath reached
Almost to painfulness. If I should kneel
Before her and implore her grace—

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Thou’dst find
Such welcome as the mountain cat might yield
To the dappled fawn; such greeting as the wolf
To the curled lamb.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh ! she would love me , father ,

Even for the prideful love of Angelo
,
That woke her hatred first. A mother joys
To tell fond legends of her children . Who : who,
Like me , would listen , with unwearied ear ,
And , when her store was ended , cry “ Again! ” again;
And every day , and all day long , be fed
With praise of that dear name? Why dost thou groan?

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: A scorpion stung me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Kill it, father , — kill it,
Before it sting again.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: Alas ! Alas , alas !
I’ll think of him no more.
sp.stage:
Enter Camillo, followed by Alberti
, L .
sp.l: Camillo, speak!
Thy breathless speed and pallid cheeks have told
A world of news already. Quick, Alberti!

Thy
tidings , man ! ,— , thy tidings!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Good my lord,

Rome is begirt with foes. The
Barons
barons
lead
Their vassals ; ,— every palace voids a horde
Of armed retainers.

sp.speaker: Rie.
sp.l: By Our Lady’s name,
I have not heard so glad a sound, since that
